text: INT. DOME TENT - BACKSTAGE — DUSK SILHOUETTE OF A MAN IN A HAT, head down. Spits... Then -- EMERGING FROM THE DARKNESS: JACKSON (JACK) MAINE (early 40s) pulls out a PRESCRIPTION PILL BOTTLE, dumps a FEW PILLS into his hand -- knocks them back -- drinks deeply from a GIN ON THE ROCKS, the alcohol spilling down his beard... the awaiting crowd just off in the b.g... A MALE ROADIE slaps him on the back.

All right, let’s do it. He walks onto -- INT. DOME TENT - MAIN STAGE —- CONTINUOUS ACTION The crowd erupting. With a wave, he flings off his hat and wields his guitar, his RHYTHM GUITARIST now opposite him... And at once in tandem they unleash dueling guitars with the sheer force of rock ‘n’ roll -- an explosion of sound as the speakers scream his latest hit, “BLACK EYES” --

(singing) ‘Black eyes open wide, It’s time to testify, There’s no room for lies, And everyone's waitin’ for you, And I'm gone, Sittin’ by the phone, And I'm all alone, By the wayside,’ The stage lights blaze from above as the song reaches its fever pitch... He may be a little drunk, but this is Jackson Maine in his element, a singer-songwriter with a mean guitar. He doesn’t just play, it’s an all-out attack. And as the song ends, we go --  INT. SUV - TIGHT - JACK’S PROFILE - LATER Camera flashes zip by across his face... stadium lighting fading away in the reflection as he knocks back a BOTTLE
PAN ALONG the bottom of a number of stalls. The bathroom seemingly empty... Until we hear a HUSHED VOICE and see two feet in heels in a stall down at the end.
(into phone) Roger... You're a wonderful man, yes, and you're a great lawyer. We're just not meant to be together.
ALLY CAMPANA, (early 30s) is on her cell phone.
(into phone) No, I don’t wanna marry you -- are you crazy?!? The hell's the matter with you? Roger, we're done. Oh, God. She hangs up, opens the door to the stall, and screams bloody murder.
Fucking men! She pulls herself together.
She walks PAST various CATERING SERVERS AND STAFF with her best friend RAMON -- he’s an aspiring dancer with a sinewy body like a swimmer, flamboyant, wonderful.
Did he cry?
He cried. He laughed. He yelled at me. You know, whatever. (CONTINUED)
You broke his heart, mama!
I did the right thing. It just wasn't right --
Ally, garbage -- They turn to see BRYAN, their catering manager, walking up from behind.
Bryan, can you get somebody else to do it for me?
You have to let her shine!
(not messing around) It’s your fucking turn!
(to Ramon) Okay, I’1l see you upstairs. He gives her a kiss and keeps moving. Ally rolls her eyes and heads towards her manager...
Come on, Bryan! She’s performing tonight!
Here we go. Taking out the trash. Like your mouth.
I'll let you go early, but you gotta finish your job.
Well, you gotta keep your mouth clean. Okay?
Ally tosses a bag of trash into the dumpster... She hums to herself, just audible over the LOUD TRASH COMPACTOR... (CONTINUED)

(singing) ‘When all the world is a hopeless jumble, And the raindrops tumble all around, Heaven opens a magic lane, When all the clouds darken up the skyway, There's a rainbow highway to be found.’ And as Ally ascends the tunnel into the night...
INT. JACK’S SUV (MOVING) - LATER THAT NIGHT The driver, PHIL, 40s, looks into the rearview mirror back to Jack, slumped against the window. Then, after a while...
Where the fuck are we?
East of the city.
(re: alcohol) Is there any more?
Sorry, Jack. And it's about an hour-forty with traffic till we get there.
Wait, really?
Yeah.
Bet we can find something around here.
I'll find something. (CONTINUED)
How’s your kid? How old is he now?
He is 17.
Fuck me.
He got a scholarship to play baseball in college already, man.
Wow, that's great.
I'm proud of him. My little guy is not so little anymore.
(moving on) I don't wanna go home.
Wish I could find you a spot. Sorry, Jack, I don't know this area.
Why don't you make a right here. INT. JACK’S SUV (MOVING) - LATER He looks out the window... He sees a BLUE NEON SIGN with some people standing out front...
Here we go. That looks like a fucking bar. As Phil slows, Jack starts to get out --

What's that say? ‘Bleu Bleu.’ Here, let me just try this. Jack gets out and slams the door behind him.  EXT./INT. “THE BLEU BLEU” - ENTRYWAY - NIGHT As Jack makes his way inside. It’s dark, his eyes adjusting when... Ramon, the host, comes over to him --
Oh, shit! Wait, wait. My man... Aren't you that... Aren't you, like...
This is a bar, right? Ramon looks around.
Yeah, but I don't know if this is your kind of place.
They got alcohol?
(stammers ) Well, yeah, but...
All right, it's my kind of place. FOLLOW JACK DEEPER INSIDE.
Oh, shit! This is crazy! How are you doing, papo? What --

How am I doing? I'm doing all right if I get a fucking drink. Someone onstage lip-syncing Etta James’ “At Last.” The place is packed... And as he settles into the bar, Ramon gestures toward the PERSON NEXT TO JACK.
Oh, this, this my homegirl, Giselle de la Isma.
Hey, how you doing? Hey.
That's Jackson Maine. (to the bartender) Excuse me, papo! Can we get this man anything he wants, please? (CONTINUED)
Can I get a gin on the rocks with a twist, please? Jack looks around...
Papo, wow. Oh, my gosh. I'm, like, freaking out right now. He’s taking in the clientele, starting to notice --
Hey, is this a drag bar?
Yeah, papo. Yeah, yeah. But, look, we do this every Friday night. It's crazy. It's so lit, though, like -- His drink arrives. He downs it.
(laughing) I thought maybe I was in some sort of hallucinogenic state.
No, no. All are welcome. All are welcome.
You gonna have something? Here, let me get you a drink.

CLOSE ON an eyelash being put on. Hair slicked back through a THREE-FOLD MIRROR cascading light from hot bulbs in a small, crowded dressing room as MEN IN DRAG (EMERALD, SOOKI, DONTE) and a few others dress, talk, and prance about.
You better get out there and kill ‘em tonight. We can’t quite make out who is at the mirror, only seeing pieces of SOMEONE.
All you ladies kill it tonight, okay? (CONTINUED)
I’m ready. I always do! They talk shit to each other -- a little chaotic, but it’s very familial and warm. They’re all made up as various famous women...
Ladies, make sure you turned in your music already. Don't make me have to come get you tonight. This is a professional show. Emerald slaps on some fake breasts.
Jack is nursing another gin chatting with a drag queen, NICKI. Ramon is surprised to see him.
You stayed! Everything good? You good?
Yeah, I'm just talking to Nicki. You know Nicki?
Oh, Nicki. How you doing, baby?
Telling me her life story. Fascinating.
Yo. My home girl's about to perform.
(over speaker) And y'all know her very well, because she used to work here as a server. But tonight, the only thing she's serving are some fabulous, French live vocals.
We see a SILHOUETTE go down a short hallway, FOLLOWING her all the way UP the side of the stage and INTO the wings, waiting to go on, and now lit from the curtains... It’s ALLY.
Is she really singing, though, or is it one of those karaoke things?
No, no, no. She's really singing, papo. I promise you, she's really singing.
Okay.
Watch this. Watch.

Ally takes a breath and goes over to the microphone... and simply begins to sing Edith Piaf’s most famous song, "La Vie En Rose” in French... In her voice an echo of the brokenhearted woman’s life is a revelation...

(singing in French) ‘Des yeux qui font baisser les miens, Un rire qui se perd sur sa bouche, Voila le portrait sans retouches, De l'homme auquel j'appartiens... And although her performance is demure in nature, she is remarkable, her voice so exceptional, talent so transcendent, Jack can’t help but just stop and listen -- Ally sings as she wanders through the audience. She crawls onto the bar, effortlessly lays back among the half-made cocktails and spirits.

Would anybody like some French tips tonight? She gets up onto the bar and begins walking toward Ramon... her performance, all done to a measured perfection minus one tiny moment where her eyes pivot and clock Jack standing there -- only to regroup and continue with the song. She lies back, seductively caressing herself with a rose and giving it to Ramon -- (CONTINUED)

She locks eyes with Jack, completely engrossed by her. Then -- Ally makes her way back to the stage as the song comes to a close. She sings the last impressive note... The LIGHTS GO OUT as the crowd hoots and hollers.
Yes, baby! Yes, baby!
Oh, fuck.
Papo, are you crying?
Ah... no.
Yo, you have to meet her.
No, no, I can't meet her.
Yes! Come on.
ALLY at her mirror, already taking off her makeup, is surrounded by drag queens.
Miss Ally mama, now you done sang in French tonight. You gonna pick something else next week?
I don’t know.
Look at her, she’s doing languages now.
Ooh, do Moroccan.
(laughing) No! Ramon guides Jack into the fray. Ally sees Jack in the reflection... (CONTINUED)
(to everyone) This is my friend, Jackson Maine.
Hey.
(down the line) This is Jackson Maine.
(one-by-one) Hi. How are you? Hey. Hey, how are ya? Hey.
Hey! Oh, my God! Right? And of course, this is my friend, Ally.
Hi.
I thought that might be you.
(leaning in) What'd you say?
I thought that might be you.
That’s me. Queens come in and out of the room, slipping past him, turning back to Ally, giving looks...
Straight man in the dressing room.
(to Jack) Do you wanna sit down?
You can -- You've been on your feet all night.
No, no. You're our guest. He sits down next to Ally. (CONTINUED)
What are you dong here?
I'm here watching the show, watching you guys.
Will you sign my boobs?
(unfazed) Sure. Yeah, I can do that.
Uh-oh. Oh, my God!
(to anyone) Give me a Sharpie!
You know, it's BYOB around here.
Yeah, is that right?
(laughs) Bring your own boobs.
Oh, those aren't really her boobs? Looking around, taking it all in.
So why are you in here, huh?
(leaning in) Sorry?
What brings you here?
Oh, I was playing right around here tonight. I'm a musician.
How'd your show go?
I think it went all right. (CONTINUED)
Emerald returns with a Sharpie in hand.
Okay, here we go. All right.
(handing it to him) Thank you!
Which one should I do?
Do ‘em both! I don't care!
Slut.
(to Ally) Bitch, Jackson Maine!
I‘ll just... Jackson autographs Emerald’s fake boobs -- “JACKSON.”
She will stop at nothing.
You gotta blow on it!

(to everyone) Thank you so much! You don't gotta go home, but you know the phrase: You gotta get the hell up outta here! 'Cause tonight, I'm not losing my virginity or my liquor license over you bitches, so pack up!
That’s right!
(to Ally) Goodbye, Roger. Have fun. Ally shares a conspiratorial look with the Emcee as she leaves --
Do you do that often? (CONTINUED)
Do what?
The show.

Yeah, yeah, the girls are so nice to me here. I mean, they would never normally let a girl sing at one of these shows, but they've always loved my voice. They used to beg me to sing. It's an honor, really. I get to be one of the gay girls.
Is that your real eyebrow?
Um, no. No. I -- (laughs) I make it out of tape.
Oh, so it's, like, stuck on?
Mm-hmm.
Can I try to take it off?
Uh, yeah, sure.
It's incredible what they do. Jack ever so gently pulls the tape eyebrow off. Ally holds
(the tape) Look at that.
(laughs) Oh. Yep. There it is.
I should put her down somewhere. her hand over her eyebrow. (CONTINUED)
There we go. (then; noticing) Why you covering your eye?
Oh. Just ‘cause I don't have my eyebrow on anymore.
Oh, no, no. The whole point is so I can see your face. Somehow Jack has grabbed Ally’s hand.
Yeah, there we go. She hesitates, but then she looks up... their eyes meet. It's altogether unexpected and exhilarating.
Why did you come back here?
Your friend brought me back here. But I'm glad he did. Can I buy you a drink?
(flustered) Oh, uh, I gotta change, and I -- I've got paint in my hair and my eyebrows are...
Oh, that's not your real hair?
No, no, my hair is, like, your color, but um... I paint it with this... makeup.
Oh, okay. I'd love to see what that looks like. I'1l wait for you.
Um, yeah, okay. Sure. Yeah, if you wanna wait, I'll come have a drink with you. Sure.  16. INT. “THE BLEU BLEU” - BAR AREA - LATER THAT NIGHT DRAG BAR EMCEE is closing out her receipts.
(to Emerald) Bitch, can you get down off that stage and come help me close this bar, please? REVEAL Emerald on stage, taking her guitar from its stand.
Don't talk to me like that in that bus driver wig, girl.
Oh, I know you did not. What you have is street appointments tonight, sister. Jack is sitting there laughing.
Excuse me! Mr. Jackson Maine, would you mind?
What do you want me to do?
Just come play a little song for me.
I don’t know.
Can you leave the man alone, please?
I showed you mine, you show me yours. Come on.
He already signed your You know you want to. Show tits, honey. Say, ‘No, off for me a little bit. sir.’
I'll only do it because you already performed, so... (CONTINUED)
You're so nice. Thank you.
Lord, the man is here for Ally. Not for you, sister.
(re: the guitar) Oh, this -- she's nice.
Isn't it cute? Little arts and crafts.
Yeah, light. Did you do this yourself?
Yeah, all me.
Does this mic -- (into microphone) -- work? Oh, yeah. Fuck, all right. (then to Emerald) What do you want me to play?
I don't care, just look at me while you do it.
Oh, Lord! Somebody kill me now. He begins to pluck the strings, something utterly different from that assault of “Black Eyes” --

(singing) ‘Maybe it's time to let the old ways die, Maybe it's time to let the old ways die, It takes a lot to change a man, Hell, it takes a lot to try, Maybe it's time to let the old ways die, Ally emerges into the room to find Jack under house lights, in the flesh and blood, feet away in a private concert for three. (CONTINUED)
Then he notices her. song comes She nods.

(singing) Nobody knows what waits dead, Nobody knows what waits dead, Some folks just believe things they've heard they read, Nobody knows what waits dead, 18. for the for the in the and things for the I'm glad I can't go back to where I came from, I'm glad those days are for good, gone, gone But if I could take spirits from my past and bring them here, you know I would, Know I would.’ to an abrupt end --
You ready?
Hmm, you know I would! OFF Ally --
Jack and Ally walking into a CROWDED DOWNTOWN BAR. — LATER THAT NIGHT they make their way -- INT. Jack and Ally now at the bar,
It’s a cop bar.
Cops?
Yeah. night long.
And sadly for everyone else, the As It's why they serve all she’s got a rum and Coke, he’s got his regular drink, gin on the rocks with a twist. (CONTINUED)
Can I ask you a personal question?
Sure.
Do you write songs or anything?
I don't sing my own songs. The bartender drops off another drink of Jack.
(to bartender) Thank you. (to Ally) Why?
I just, I just don't feel comfortable.
Why wouldn't you feel comfortable?
Um... Well, ‘cause, like, almost every single person that I've come in contact with in the music industry has told me that my nose is too big and that I won't make it.
Your nose is too big?
Yeah.
Your nose is beautiful. Jack looks at her, dumbfounded. She turns her head profile, takes her finger and runs it down from her forehead, over her nose, down to her chin.
Are you showing me your nose right now? She embarrassingly smiles. (CONTINUED)
Yeah.
You don't have to show it to me. I've been looking at it all night.
Oh, come on.
Oh, I'm gonna be thinking No, you're not. You're about your nose for a very full of shit. long time.
I'm not full of shit.
Yeah, you are.
I'm telling you the truth.
Yeah, you're full of shit.
Can I touch your nose?
Oh, my gosh.
Let me just touch it for a second. She laughs, but he’s serious. He reaches in, she lets him. His finger brushes the top of her nose, intimate, surreal.
You're very lucky.
Oh, really? (he nods) Yeah, not really. My nose has not made me lucky. (beat) I could've had, maybe, a hit song if it wasn't for my nose.
That's fucking bullshit. (CONTINUED)

Yeah. No, it's not bullshit, because, you go into these rooms and there’s all these fucking men in there and they’re just staring at you, listening to your record going, ‘Oh, you sound great, but, you know, you don’t look so great.’

You know, I had a thing when I was little. I was born with this thing in my ear. Couldn’t hear... What do I wind up being? A singer. So you never know... (then) Look... Talent comes everywhere, everybody’s talented. I bet you, fucking everybody in this bar is talented in one thing or another, but having something to say, and a way to say it so people listen to it, that’s a whole other bag. And unless you get out there and you try to do it you’1l never know. That’s just the truth. If there’s one reason we’re supposed to be here, it’s to say something so people wanna hear it. She's looking at him. They share
Don't you understand what I'm trying to tell you?
Yeah, I do... I don't like it. But I understand it. a smile.
Oh, I think you like it a little bit. I think I'm getting through a little bit, I can see it.
No, you can't.
It's a good thing we met... (CONTINUED)
Yeah.
For both of us, trust me.
I mean, I don't know what is going on, honestly --
Who does?
I'm in a cop bar, with Jackson Maine, and it's, like...
(laughing) I'm gonna wake up in a Jackson Maine. minute.
That's the thing about when you get famous, people start saying your full name.
Well, what do you want me to --
Well, it’s just ‘Jack.’ The jukebox has started to play a song of Jack’s: “Too Far Gone.” The PERSON at the jukebox just continues to pick songs.
Speaking of... Come on.
What?
Did you put that on? He listens closely. She can tell that he’s straining to hear it.
When did you even go to the jukebox?
Oh, God, I hear that song and I just want to turn it the fuck off. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
I fucked that fucking song up so bad --
Hey! She laughs just as a YOUNG POLICEMAN (TOMMY), slurring and aggressive --
(to Jack) I know that we're not supposed to do this... I know that we're not supposed to come and bother you, you come here every night...
It’s alright.
(to his buddies) You got your camera on you? I don't have my camera on me.
Let’s just -- He stumbles back into Jack, too close.
(to Jack again) Excuse me, one sec -- My ex- girlfriend was fucking this guy...
Right. Okay. Ally puts her hand over her face, looking to Jack, like, “I'm so sorry...”
Who looks just like you, that’s what she said.
(sotto) Shut the hell up...
But I gotta take a picture of you because I gotta send it to her, ‘cause I'm gonna show her you look nothing fucking like that fucking guy! (CONTINUED)
Okay, that’s enough, Tommy. (to his buddy) Jack, I'm sorry. Dave, take a picture... Ally gets up, maybe to intervene.
(to the buddy) Well, maybe that'll help her out. (back to Tommy) Will that help you? Would that make you happy? Tommy gets into Jack’s space, stumbling into him to pose for the picture...
Okay, why don’t we take the fucking picture.
Let her visualize it.
You want someone to take your picture? Ally steps up to him.
(pushing her aside) Excuse me.
I‘ll help you take a picture. Ally pulls his hand away and, in doing so, he gets rough with her.
Get your hand off me, you fucking little whore!
What?! Ally punches him in the face... sending him back into the crowded bar. Everyone in the vicinity takes note... Things get out of control for a second --
I got you. It’s alright... Jack grabs her, pulling her out of the room and laughing at the absurdity of it all --  25.
Fluorescent lighting... Jack walking up and down the aisles, looking for something -- Ally trying to keep up...
I'm fine, honestly. I'm okay. This is so stupid.
You gotta get ahead of the swelling. Just try to find some...
This is so embarrassing. Jack pulls a bag of frozen peas from the freezer and puts it on her hand.
Here we go. Put that on there. Gotta wrap something up with it. Find a... Jack grabs a bag of Cheetos.
You like Cheetos?
No, like, gauze. Some gauze or something.
Gauze? Jack stops to look at her hand to see if it’s starting to swell. He holds it, looking at it with her...
(flexing his hand) Try to do that. She tries, but can’t really.
With that hand. And do that hand. You play piano? (as she nods) Yeah, we gotta take care of this, then. He walks away.  26.
The CASHIER is swiping their items.
It's already gotten warm, hasn't it? Should we have gotten two?
No, it's okay. Thanks. CLICK. The Cashier is holding up her phone and just took a picture, Ally not quite in frame...
I'm sorry. I had to.
That's all right. Have a good one.
It's not really all right, but... And as they stumble out --
Be careful, she'll hit ya.
Jack's SUV parked, Phil, the driver eating the Cheetos off a ways, Jack and Ally sitting outside the store side- by-side on a parking block.
These rings are gonna get stuck if you don't take 'em off... Does that hurt?
Yeah. That's okay...
(holding her hand) May I?
Yeah. Jack sucks on her finger, wetting it and slipping the rings off, places them in his pocket. (CONTINUED)
Safe keeping. Jack reaches for the frozen peas.
Put this on there.
You're sweet.
Just wrap it up... You'll be good to go. He puts it on her hand and WRAPS IT with GAUZE and TAPE.
How the hell do you deal with that all the time?
What's that?
People just talking to you like you're not a real person. Or taking your picture --
Is that too tight?
It's okay. He tears the wrap with his teeth --
Did I hurt you?
It's fine, it's okay. He finishes wrapping the package of peas to her hand.
There you go, now you're mobile. Swing it around. They start to laugh. It looks ridiculous.
I look like a pirate. (CONTINUED)
A beat... 28.
I told you it was worth coming here.
How do you do that?
Do what?
Don't change the subject.
Is that what I'm doing?
Nobody ever asked you about you, huh?
Not sure.
Where you from?
Arizona.
Arizona boy.
Dad had like a midlife crisis, I think, so I've been told. Made his way to Arizona, started working for this family on a pecan ranch.
A pecan ranch...
Yeah... Knocked up the family's daughter, she was just shy of eighteen.
Uh-oh.
That's when I came into the picture. (CONTINUED)
Okay, the son of an eighteen-year- old.
Well, she died at childbirth. And my dad --
I’m sorry.

He died when I was thirteen, so, I guess my brother will tell you that he raised me, but I don't know... I don't know who was raising who. Just a hundred- twenty-seven acres of nuts, Navajo, and nowhere to go. She looks at him, he’s gone inside himself a bit, looking down, doesn’t usually share this much -- A beat...
(singing) ‘Tell me something boy, Aren’t you tired tryin’ to fill that void? Or do you need more, Ain’t it hard keepin’ it so hardcore?’
Is that me?
That’s you.
You just write that now?
Yeah.
It's pretty good.
(singing) ‘I’m falling, In all the good times, I find myself longing for change.’ (CONTINUED)
She starts to get up.
I started writing this song the other day, and... She gets up off the curb and into the parking lot, her very own stage...

Maybe that could work, like, as a chorus or something. I have to think if I can remember it. (singing) ‘I’m off the deep end, Watch as I dive in, I’ll never meet the ground, Crash through the surface, Where they can’t hurt us, We’re far from the shallow now.’
Holy shit. She starts to laugh, noticing her pea-wrapped hand.
(laughing) What is this? Was this supposed to help me? She sits back down next to him. He leans into her.
Can I tell you a secret? Closer now, and whispering --
I think you might be a songwriter. She downcasts her eyes away from him.
But don't worry, I won't tell anybody. But I'm not very good at keeping secrets. He kisses her hand.
You're a real gentleman. (beat; then) I think. (CONTINUED)

She places her hand on his cheek and they sit there, holding in this moment, not wanting the night to end. EXT. ALLY’S HOUSE (THE VALLEY) - EARLY MORNING Jack's SUV pulling up in front of a house with three identical BLACK SUVs parked along the curb --
Thank you, sir. It's right here, on the right. INT./EXT. THE SUV (PARKED)/ALLY’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS
It’s the time Ally should probably get out of the car and yet, she and Jack sit there quietly together. They don’t want to leave each other, the night still running through their veins --
(re: SUVs) What’s all this?
It’s my dad. It’s a long story.
What's he, a sheikh?
No, he's a driver.
Hey, I got a gig. You wanna come?
When?
We're headed to the airport now.
Well, it's tonight. She looks up at the sky, the sun has come up...
Tonight? No, I can't. I gotta go to work later. I gotta go to bed. She begins gathering her things. (CONTINUED)
Who's gonna take care of your hand? I messed it up.
Me. I'll take care of my hand.
It's my fault I took you to that place. She opens the SUV door and slides out.
That’s okay. You have my number.
Okay. All right. She shuts the door and starts to walk off... Jack lowers the window.
Hey. Ally turns back.
What?
I just wanted to take another look at you. Ally slides her finger down her nose just the way Jack did at the cop bar. She walks inside. The SUV drives off.

(sotto) I don't know, maybe I fucked that up. INT. ALLY’S HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER Ally walks up the stairs and a distinctive, manicured, fastidious-looking man in his early sixties, wearing a black suit and a black tie: LORENZO CAMPANA, meets her on the landing.
Pretty late... pretty late. (CONTINUED)
Oh, is it late?
Come on.
I wanna go to bed.
No, come in for two minutes. The guys... It's Wolfie's birthday, come on... (as she considers) Two minutes...
Okay. (to Wolfie; shouts) Wolfie! Ally moves past him towards the kitchen.
Yeah, sweetheart?
Who was the guy in the car?

I don't know what you're talking about. And as they pass the dining room we see racing forms cluttering the table; MATTY, an older driver watching a live broadcast of a racetrack from Japan where the horses are approaching the starting gate. The announcer speaking rapid Japanese.
Hey, Ally. Ally moves into the kitchen where a waiting WOLFIE stands reading a racing form.
(to Wolfie) How's it going? Happy birthday.
Hey, ‘happy birthday’?
Yeah. (CONTINUED)
It's not my birthday.
(to Lorenzo) What do you mean?
No, I was just saying, like... Ally sees the kitchen -- It’s a disaster.
Come on. What the hell happened in here? My God! This place is a mess!
(re: racing form) Starting gate is... ‘Shuppatsu geto...’ and bad beat is ‘Warui bito.' Ally immediately begins cleaning.
Who the hell's betting on horses at breakfast time in Japan?
It's not breakfast time in Japan. Wolfie laughs... A toilet flushes 0.S. and LITTLE FEET has appeared to the group.
They're loading!
Renzo, we're going. Come on!
It'll wait, they're loading -- And we see the horses loading into the starting gate as the men assemble around the dining room table to watch the race, clearly a ritual.
You guys are crazy.
Have a sizable investment on this thing here. (CONTINUED)
(from the kitchen) What did I say about smoking in this house? Ally comes in to clear the dishes and ashtrays.
(to Wolfie) Outside!
Who are you?
Who am I? It's my house.
I know it's your house. But you smoke, too.
All right, forget it. Okay, guys.
Sweetheart, you're happy here, aren't you? Ally continues to clean up the dishes.
I'm happy, Dad.
(stuttering) I'm just saying, she's got no space.
What are you saying? Ally begins to head to the kitchen, Lorenzo tries to stop her.
Wait a minute, sweetheart. Wait a minute. Wait a minute! I want my friends to look at you.
He said she's got no space. She halts, arms full of dirty dishes. Lorenzo smiles at his daughter, looking at her. (CONTINUED)

Take a good look. With a voice, like, from Heaven, but you know what? It's not always the best singers that make it. You know? Ally’s not hearing this speech again and so heads back into the kitchen. Lorenzo continues to hold court at the dining room table.

I knew a couple guys, could sing Sinatra under the table. But Frank, he'd come on stage with the blue eyes, the sharkskin suit, the patent leather shoes. He becomes Frank Sinatra. And everybody else, all these other guys, that really got it, that really have it inside... just a bunch of nobodies. Ally listens until she’s had enough.

Okay. Everybody, let's go. Time for work. INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE - DAY Jack has a pair of headphones on. We hear a high-pitched noise. He holds up one finger. He takes off the headphones, revealing a HEARING DOCTOR.
Unfortunately, you keep blasting the hearing, it's not gonna come back. I think it's time we reconsider the inner monitors.
Mm-hmm.
We talked about that with Bobby a couple of weeks ago.
Yup, yup. Yeah. (CONTINUED)
If we put the inner moles in, we can actually use those to amplify the high frequencies and cut down the sound.
Yeah, okay, that sounds great. Yeah, you're right. Yeah.
I'm gonna talk to Bobby, and we're gonna get something set up.
Sold. I'm sold. Yeah, call Bobby.
A cowboy of a man of indeterminate age, a man who's seen it all twice, who wears miles of rough road, who we'll come to know as BOBBY, barrels into the amphitheater.
Stubborn son of a bitch.

(over speaker) All right, let's get ready. One, two, three, four. Snippets of direction echo through the sound system to CREW setting up and calibrating equipment -- JACK’S BAND onstage rehearsing to the empty amphitheater, technicians and roadies busy setting up for a performance --
It's loud, too loud, and the band is trying to play it through --

(over speaker; singing) ‘Killin’ me baby with the things you do, You put me in the ground.’ The sound overpowering... Bobby walking up to the stage and as he’s arriving, the DRUMS stop, then the BASS, then everything else, but Jack plays on, into it until he stops abruptly -- (CONTINUED)
(over speaker) We're trying... Bobby holding up Jack’s earpiece.
You gotta put ‘em in, man.
I told you, I can't wear those things. When I wear 'em, it's just in my head, and I need to be here with everybody else. How the fuck am I gon--
(interrupting) The doctor said it's the only way to manage this thing, Jack. You're not gonna get back what you lost. It's the only way we can manage what you still got.
Oh, wow. I think we're managing pretty good.
What do you want me to do? Jack speaks into the mic, his voice echoing through the venue --
(into mic) You know the door's wide open if you wanna go.
You know what? Don't start that shit. (beat) Show a little fucking pride in what you're doing, buddy.
(re: Ally) I just wanna know if she's on her way or not, that's all.
Who's coming? What the fuck?  39. INT. ALLY’S HOUSE - DAY We hear opera as Ally runs down the stairs in a T-shirt and shorts.
Who's here?
I have no idea. He won't tell me.
She opens the door to find Phil, the driver, waiting...
Hi, Ally.
Hi.
I'm Phil. We met last night. Lorenzo, over her shoulder...
Yeah, I remember.
Jack sent me to pick you up and take you to the gig.
Oh, my God. I gotta work. I can't go.
He’s really looking forward to this. She gently shuts the door saying...
I appreciate that, but...
I can't leave, so I'll be in my car right down the street.
Uh, please tell him, ‘Thank you, but no thank you.’ (CONTINUED)
Well...
Okay? Say it just like that. She slams the door in his face and heads to the kitchen with Lorenzo in pursuit.
Wait a minute, Ally. What are you doing?
What the fuck is that shit? This is crazy.
What are you doing? This is great. Look, a guy like that invites you to a show?
Dad, don't start with me.
I mean, it could be a great Don't start! opportunity.
Listen, listen! Does he know you sing at all? Did he, did he hear anything from you?
Dad, I gotta go to work.
This could be the opportunity of a lifetime.
I don't have the same disease that you have, Dad. You get around celebrities and it's like they're gonna rub off on you, you know?
What are you talking about? What are you talking about? (CONTINUED)
‘Oh, you know who I drove the other day?’ Like magic, now you're famous. And you're not. It's not magic, Dad. With that, she heads up the stairs.
Sweetheart. I'm just --
He's a drunk! You know all about drunks! And she disappears into her bedroom... Lorenzo's quiet. He starts back downstairs...
Sweetheart, he's still there.
Ramon and Ally are walking up stairs in their uniforms.
Yo, so you fucking hit a cop?
Yeah, he was being an asshole to Jack, so I fucking popped him in the face.
Yo, that is so gangster.

And so, then we ended up ina parking lot, and he put peas around my hand to fix it. And then he was singing, and I was singing. I don't know what the hell's going on. But now he's got his driver following me around.
Wait, he's been following you from your house all the way to work?
Yes! It's crazy!  42. INT. THE BILTMORE - KITCHEN - PREP AREA -— CONTINUOUS
That same catering crew is back at work again tonight.
Are you gonna go with him, ‘cause if you don't go, I will go. Bryan walks by.
You're fucking late again.
(a shout to Bryan) I’m what?
I said you're late!
We begin to faintly hear INSTRUMENTAL GUITAR being played live somewhere... Calling her...
Are we doing this? The guitar builds as Ally starts to walk out of the kitchen. Ramon starts after her.
Hey, Bryan, I'm out. Find somebody else.
Bryan, I'll be back. I promise. Papo, I promise.
See ya. I won't. INT./EXT. JACK’S SUV - MOMENTS LATER Music builds as Ally and Ramon are ready for the night and walk to Jack’s waiting SUV.
(out of the window) Hey, great! Let's do this. (CONTINUED)
Ally and Ramon get in the car and they share a giddy smile at what might lay ahead.
What are we doing?

(to Phil) You know, if I didn't know Jack... I would call you a stalker. EXT. SANTA MONICA AIRPORT - TARMAC —- SUNDOWN The SUV stopped on the tarmac alongside a private plane. Ally and Ramon get out of the car, Ramon pirouetting his way onto the plane -- the music still going...
Ally and Ramon explore the interior of the luxurious private jet, taking it all in. Lay on the couches, play on the televisions, loving it.
I could get used to this shit. You need to date more rock stars, baby girl, you know what I'm saying?
We're not dating. The music still building...

A Town Car pulling up at the venue, the music now audible, they’re right there... and GAIL, a frenetic type of woman, is waiting for her. She opens the door for Ally. Ramon gets out the other side of the Town Car, on his phone, recording this once in a lifetime experience.
Hi, Ally, I’m Gail... You guys can leave your bags -- we'll grab 'em in asec. Ready? And with that said, Ally gets out of the car and they follow Gail --
Okay, sure. (CONTINUED)
Did you have a good trip?
Yeah.
(handing them over) Passes.
Oh, thank you.

Put ‘em around your necks. Earplugs. You'll need these, it's loud up there. (into radio) Yeah, I got 'em. We're coming in. (to Ally and Ramon) I'm gonna bring you guys to the side stage. Gail picks up the pace, Ally almost running after her... The music growing louder with every step... She looks back to Ramon to pick up the pace and then he’s there, taking up her arm and walking in stride, getting closer and closer...
Guys, this way.
This place is so big. This is crazy.

He's excited that you're here. They walk around a wall of amps and through PEOPLE onto SIDE STAGE LEFT, where we FIND Jack, drenched with sweat, playing along with his band in the middle of the stage in front of thousands. She squeezes Ramon’s arm... She can't help but be taken by the overwhelming power of the whole thing...

(into mic; singing) ‘I told my dyin' daddy that I had to run away, Looked him in the eye and said, There ain't no other way, So, woman, if I tell you that I love you, be okay, ‘Cause I ain't lyin’, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

I don't lie, Without an alibi, ‘Cause I ain't lyin', I don't lie, Without an alibi.’ And Jack instinctively turns and sees Ally... ending the guitar solo, into the chorus refrain that he belts out with two other players... Ally watches his every move, time seems to slow down for her, out of body, wanting to experience each and every moment... it’s all second nature to Jack... And as the song ends...

(into mic) Thank you very much. That was great... There's a friend of mine, who came a long way to be here... She wrote a great song, and I'd just like her to sing it. I think it's pretty fucking good. The audience cheers. He motions her on the stage... and now she is hit with severe self-consciousness, she doesn't want that... she starts to walk off... Jack bounds over to her, taking her hand...
How are you? You made it!
I'm good. Hil!
It's so good to see you. How are you? That was so good.
So, listen, we're gonna sing that song, all right? I did an arrangement, it was kind of not so great. But... maybe you could just stick with it.
(stammering) No, I can't do that. I'm sorry.
Here we go. He tries to drag her by the hand onto the stage. She is frozen, shaking her head... (CONTINUED)
Jack, please. It's not funny. Jack, don't fuck around.
Oh, my God. Ramon backs away from their struggle. She won't succumb, she adamantly shakes “no”... Jack comes closer into her --
All you gotta do is trust me. She frees her hand... starting to walk off into the shadows to hide...
(returning to the stage) That's all you gotta do. I'm gonna sing it either way, so...
(sotto voce) ‘Trust me.’ Okay.
You have to go sing.
I'm not going out there, no. Jack starts to play a familiar melody reminding us of the song she came up with the night before. He starts to sing the first verse --
(into mic; singing) ‘Tell me somethin’, girl, Are you happy in this modern world?, Or do you need more, Is there somethin’ else you're searchin’ for?,’ In fact, that is exactly what it is, “SHALLOW.”
(into mic; singing) ‘I'm fallin’, In all the good times, I find myself longin’ for change, (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

And in the bad times I fear myself...’ And he stops and looks at her, imploring her verse. She turns and looks at him. Jack just standing there on stage willing to sit in the silence. Just looking at her... Waiting... One moment feels like forever until Ally summons the courage steps on stage and starts to sing from the wings --

(into mic; singing) ‘Tell me something, boy, Aren't you tired, tryin’ to fill that void?, Or do you need more, Ain't it hard keepin’ it so hardcore?, I'm falling, In all the good times, I find myself longing for change, And in the bad times, I fear myself, (chorus ) I'm off the deep end, Watch as I dive in, I'll never meet the ground, Crash through the surface, Where they can't hurt us, We're far from the shallow now...’ And as she finishes singing the chorus to him, his band joins in.

(into mic; singing) ‘In the sha-ha-sha-ha-low, In the sha-ha-sha-la-la-la-low, In the sha-ha-sha-ha-ha-low, We're far from the shallow now...’ He motions her to take the downstage microphone. She’s come this far -- She walks further onto the stage and belts out the chorus.
(into mic; singing) ‘I'm off the deep end, Watch as I dive in, I never meet the ground, Crash through the surface, Where they can't hurt us, We're far from the shallow now...’ (CONTINUED)
And the crowd goes wild.

(into mic; singing) ‘In the sha-ha-sha-ha-low In the sha-ha-sha-la-la-la-low In the sha-ha-sha-ha-ha-low We're far from the shallow now...’ And as they sing together, thousands of iPHONES raise, recording the moment... Jack singing with her as if he was a boy and nothing will ever be the same again... And as the song comes to a close, she can’t believe it. Jack senses her shock and goes to her.
Oh, my God! There's so Pretty fucking good... many people. Pretty fucking good. We see from -- ALLY’S POV all of it new to her, surreal and frightening, and at once euphoric...
Ally is following Jack as he weaves THROUGH the tunnels of the amphitheater TO an opening, a loading dock, where she first arrived...
I think the way the guitar just started, and...
I thought maybe I set it in the wrong key, and then the tempo was too fast.
No, it was so beautiful, and...
I wasn't sure... Then, without warning, they are mobbed by a mass of people, vying for Jack... “Jackson, Jackson...” PEOPLE take selfies with him as he walks by, a blur of faces... (CONTINUED)
Jack? She looks around for Jack for respite... but she’s lost him. An unexpected moment of panic washing over her... When --
(with Ally now) Hey, hey, hey. You all right?
Jackson!/Good concert, man!/Isn't that the girl who sang? Good concert!
Thank you, yeah. Thank Jackson, I love you, man. you. And as they are about the board the bus, Bobby is there.
Hey, Jack. Killed it.
Really?

Yeah. And during this moment between them, Ally feels the eyes of a young MAN, confident beyond his years. We’1ll come to know him as REZ. Jack pulls Ally into his trailer where a big crowd is partying. Jack puts his cowboy hat on her head where she receives an encore from Jack's band.
Jack stumbles down the long corridor of the hotel with Ally in tow. A little loaded, he searches for the key, but in which pocket? He finds it and they enter the room.
They barge in; he turns and kisses her. Ecstatic, if not sloppy... and as they catch their breath with the hint of something more to come... (CONTINUED)
I'll be right back, okay? Just give me one second. She pulls away as Jack stumbles, a toxic rush of blood to the head.
(sotto voce) Where's the fucking bathroom? She finds it and goes into the bathroom. Jack makes his way to the couch, lights a cigarette, and lies down.

Ally looks into the mirror. Jesus. What is happening right now. Ally wets a towel, gives it the ol’ once-over and lets out a breath and goes back into -- INT. HOTEL - ROOM —- CONTINUOUS ACTION She turns the corner in eager anticipation only to find Jack passed out.
Hey, Jack?
RAMON’S ROOM Ramon is shirtless at his hotel room door, music, laughter from within which he’s inclined to return to --
I don't know, wake him up.
I can't wake him up. He's drunk.
Yes, you can! Shake your titties in his face or some shit... You know what I'm saying? Take two shots and -- (CONTINUED)
(sarcastic) Thank you so much for your help. You are so helpful.
Let me know how it goes, baby. She walks off. INT. HOTEL - ROOM —- CONTINUOUS ACTION Ally returns to where Jack was but -- Bobby is putting Jack into bed.
(to Jack) C’mon, pal. And, used to it, Bobby perfunctorily puts a pillow under his head. Ally watches Bobby handle Jack with a surprising tenderness -- He looks at her...
He’s out. (then; laughing at her willful naiveté) You think maybe he drinks a bit much? Sweetie, you have no idea. He starts to walk off, but turns to her --
Tell you one thing, though. He's never brought a girl onstage before. (beat) And it's been a long, long time since he played like that.

Well, that's good to know. And leaving her all alone, Ally sits on the edge of the bed, while Jack sleeps. Watching him sleep, alone with her moment of glory. She starts to hum the melody to “Somewhere Over the Rainbow” ever so lightly as she undresses and climbs under the covers with him, looking small... The two of them quite a pair...  52.

Ally under the covers, asleep beside Jack. His eyes open. He comes awake, finding his bearings. He sees her next to him asleep. He looks at her back. He moves closer, tenderly kissing her shoulders. She murmurs, coming awake. He kisses her neck. She rolls over. He kisses her face. Her lips. She pulls him closer as they make love in the witching hour... what feels like a real love...
Jack in his shirt and underwear and Ally in a hotel robe sitting around the dining table, eating breakfast.

One time, my brother came home... I was playing on this upright we used to always have in our den. And I was, like, in my own world. And no one was ever home, and he comes home to take care of my dad, who was sick. And he's sitting there, and he's looking at me. And I swear to God, he looked at me like I was special or something, and it just kind of filled me up, and... I should've never told you that. I don't know.
Why?
‘Cause it's embarrassing. I don't know.
It's so sweet.
‘Cause you're nothing like my brother.
Yeah, I don't look like your brother? (CONTINUED)
He's a fucking old man. My dad had me when he was sixty-three years old.
Sixty-three years old?
And we have different mothers, SO...

head_text.subj: WE'RE LOOKING AT A YOUTUBE VIDEO OF THEIR DUET.

text: What's that number down here?
That is how many people looked at it.
And we see Lorenzo's racetrack and driver compadres are clustered together in Ally's living room, as one of them is holding a cell phone for the others to see...
Get the fuck outta here. How do they know how many people looked at it?
They call it an algorithm...
What's an algorithm?
It’s like a beat.
A beat?
Yeah.
Like in music, a beat? (CONTINUED)
Yeah. Lorenzo comes in and sees what they’re looking at...
Do you believe this? And you see this? He points to the growing number on the screen.
Yeah.
That's how many people have watched.
Yeah, yeah, we... We were telling him.
How the fuck do they do that?
I watched it two hundred times myself. I'm two hundred of those people.
Go, Pops.
Jack races Ally back to the bed, but he grabs her, carries her into the bedroom; they crash among the sheets and blankets. EXT. ALLY’S HOUSE (THE VALLEY) - LATER A TAXI pulls up...
(pre-lap) Beautiful. You wrote this with him? INT. ALLY’S HOUSE Ally and Lorenzo are watching the video. (CONTINUED)
He's so talented. (it ends) Can we watch it again? Just one more time.
One more time.
Or, like... five hundred...
I'll be up all night watching this!

Ally lies in bed, peaceful, asleep despite the sun already peeking in. A gentle hand touches her, sweeps the hair from her face. She startles awake to see Jack, there in her bedroom, on her bed, in her life. They kiss real.
Oh, my God. How did you get in here?
Dad, let me in.
(trying to make sense of it) What? and hold each other. Suddenly, this is very
I don't feel this way about everybody.
Well, good. Then we're on the same page. You come and sing with me.
Where?
Well, first stop's Arizona.  56. OUTSIDE ALLY’S BATHROOM Jack waits while Ally showers. She comes out and sees the motorcycle helmets in his hands. She spies his motorcycle parked outside.
I'm never getting on that thing with you when you've been drinking.
I haven't even thought about drinking or anything else.
We'll see how long that lasts. Go wait downstairs.
Lorenzo talks Jack’s ear off.
Actually, when I was, like, in my twenties and thirties, I was, like, a crooner. As a matter of fact, a lot of people thought I was better than Sinatra.
Jesus.
Frank? Frank Sinatra? All Lorenzo's buddies explode with laughter.
The motorcycle flies along a stretch of desert highway. Ally rides on the back of Jack's motorcycle as they cross the state line into Arizona.

Jack is still holding his helmet, looking through a GLASS CASE picking out toppings to TACOS. He goes back to their booth, where Ally is sitting with her SONGBOOK. Ally scribbles down some notes. (CONTINUED)
She mimics 57.
What are you writing down in here?
That's my songbook. I usually use a typewriter, but... I had this idea on the bike, and I didn't wanna forget it.
How do you hear it? playing the piano, singing the percussive beats to a song still emerging. She pours
(singing) ‘I’m alone in my house.’ herself a glass of water and, keeping the conversation going --
Aren't you excited to be home and play for all your Arizonian fans?
I don't really come back here.
You avoid your home?

I don't know. The hot air and the... history, I don't know. Bought the ranch I grew up on... Gave it to my brother. We buried Dad there... I just wanted to make sure that nobody paved over his grave or any of that kind of shit.
Is it around here?
It's not far.
Why don't we just go there? It's nearby.  58.
Jack finished pumping gas, puts the GAS NOZZLE back, and screws the GAS CAP back on. She looks up at him as he straps her helmet on her and kisses her. They ride off...
IT’S A VAST WIND FARM, stretching into the distance... Jack standing, looks around... Ally in the distance looks around as well...
Jack? Then to Jack... It’s as if all the life has been sucked out of him. He tries to speak, but the words don’t come... He bends down and sifts some dry sand through his fingers.
Bobby is going over a SET LIST with a TECH.
Whenever he shows up. These guys have been vamping out there for a fucking half an hour. It's time to fucking get on. He looks up to see Jack --
Don't you get tired of being...
Jack DECKS Bobby with a hard punch sending him flat to the ground --
You sold Dad's ranch! They turned it into a fucking wind farm! Bobby's trying to get his bearings, but he’s dazed...
I bought that for you. (CONTINUED)
Where's his grave?

(exploding) He washed away in a fucking storm. His grave isn't there anymore. I would have told you, but you were fucking drunk. You were fucking loaded and already pissing yourself a swan song. Fuck if you shed a tear for that piece of shit you idolize for no goddamn fucking reason. All Dad ever did for you... is make you his fucking drinking buddy. And you'd be right there with him if he was still alive, and you fucking know it. Ally looks at Jack, his head down, thinking god knows what... But Bobby grabs Jack’s face, pulling him close, nose-to-nose, nowhere to hide.
What did you think, that I was gonna fucking take care of it while I'm fucking cradling your ass all over the goddamn world?
That's a good excuse. Raising a little brother, so you don't have to deal with the fact that you were no fucking good.
If I was no good, why'd you steal my fucking voice?
‘Cause you had nothing to fucking say. And you were too proud to sing any of the songs I ever wrote.
(after a beat) Well, I got something to say now, pal. I'm done being your fucking errand boy. I quit. And Bobby’s gone. Jack opens the door to the dressing room...  60.
Jack is standing, shirt off, pants halfway down as a DOCTOR administers a steroid shot in his bottom.
Yeah, my voice just got up on me a few months ago and... another shot of steroids is better safe than sorry. The doctor finishing... Hands him a prescription bottle. This is a routine.
Thank you for that and, yeah, we should be good.
Ally recovering from the fight that just happened, washing her face. She steps out of the bathroom to find Jack. Jack notices Ally taking all this in as well as how beautiful she looks.
Hey. You okay?
Yeah.
Well, let's play.
WALKING WITH JACK AND ALLY as they make their way as Ally stops and just watches as Jack grabs his guitar and heads effortlessly onto the stage... as we --
We see Jack looking out the window to what looks like a makeshift city erected in the middle of the English countryside... as we --
Erupting applause from the AUDIENCE. The music kicks in, and it’s the song, “ALIBI.” Jack attacks the guitar. Ally plays the piano.

(into mic; singing) ‘Don't ask me ‘bout tomorrow, Or tell me ‘bout my past, My heart is yours to borrow, Ain't nothin’ meant to last, I ain't lyin’.’ THOUSANDS OF PEOPLE IN THE CROWD ALL LISTENING -——
As we see Jack play a familiar song, “MAYBE IT’S TIME.”
(into mic; singing) ‘Maybe it's time to let the old ways die,’
The tour bus hustles onward as the eastern sky begins to kindle --
(into mic; singing) ‘Maybe it's time to let the old ways die, It takes a lot to change a man, Hell, it takes a lot to try, Maybe it's time to let the old ways die,’
The band disembarks the bus one-by-one, and Ally, too, one of them now, with Jack, ready for the next one.
(into mic; singing) ‘Nobody knows what waits for the dead, Nobody knows what waits for the dead,’  62.
Ally lies awake into the night, scribbles songs in her notebook as Jack sleeps beside her.
(into mic; singing) ‘Some folks just believe in the things they've heard and things they read, Nobody knows what waits for the dead,’
Jack and Ally sing together on stage, nose-to-nose -- she slaps the tambourine, lost in the music.

(into mic; singing) ‘I'm glad I can't go back to where I came from, I'm glad those days are gone, gone for good, But if I could take spirits from my past and bring them here, you know I would, Know I would.’ And as their unheard performance comes to a close, Jack’s song and words fade into the diegetic sounds of a crowd wanting more, not wanting the concert to end, the shout and chant which beckons an encore -- They continue -- END MONTAGE.
Jack and Ally JUST OFF STAGE, the energy palpable; the euphoria of performing still coursing through their veins and, in particular, Ally’s -- the AUDIENCE ROARS in the b.g. urging on the encore...
All right, I got an idea for the end. Jack lights a joint. Tequila shots are poured. (CONTINUED)
It's gonna be a little different, we're gonna...
Cheers. They all throw back the tequila...
Where’s that joint? We're just gonna be a little different for the end, okay? We're gonna do the encore and the thing that I said.
Okay. All right. The crowd's applause and whistles urging their return...
All right? Come on, let's go back out and do it. Go, go, go. And walking back to the wings just off stage --
(following him) What? What are you doing? He stops just short of the stage and turns to her, holding her...
All right, listen to me. Here's what we're gonna do. You're gonna do the song that I said that I wanted you to do, remember? The one that I love.
No. No, I'm not. Please! Yeah, you're gonna do the Come on. one that I love. It's gonna be great, come on.
Come on, Jack. Please don’t.
I‘ll always... You promised me you were gonna do it --
I always say -- (CONTINUED)
I love you... He kisses her.
Always remember us this way. And he leaves her there in the wings...

(over speakers) Everybody, we're gonna bring out Ally to bring us home... and she's gonna sing an original song. Thank you. Ally pours herself another shot of tequila and gulps it down. There's big applause. Ally walks --

looking at the piano. She’s caught between what she so badly wants and what is stopping her... She looks at Jack, who smiles his encouragement, making her feel safe, despite her deepest fears, she goes over to the piano... Ally looks out at the audience... Here she goes, into the abyss...

(into mic; singing) ‘That Arizona sky, Burnin’ in your eyes, You look at me and, babe, I wanna catch on fire, It's buried in my soul, Like California gold, You found the light in me that I couldn't find,’ And she starts to play and sing an original song... which makes the night stand still... the world at her feet...
(into mic; singing) ‘So when I'm all choked up and I can't find the words, Every time we say goodbye, baby, it hurts, When the sun goes down, And the band won't play, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

I'll always remember us this way, Lovers in the night, Poets tryin' to write, We don't know how to rhyme but damn we try, But all I really know, You're where I wanna go, The part of me that's you will never die,’ But for now, in this glorious moment, people on their iPhones are recording it for posterity... one of those times where people will tell you they were there when Ally Campana sang on her own for the very first time...

(into mic; singing) ‘So when I'm all choked up and I can't find the words, Every time we say goodbye, baby, it hurts, When the sun goes down And the band won't play, I'll always remember us this way, Oh, yeah, I don't wanna be just a memory, baby, yeah, So when I'm all choked up and I can't find the words, Every time we say goodbye, baby, it hurts, When the sun goes down and the band won't play, I'll always remember us this way, Way, yeah, When you look at me and the whole world fades, I'll always remember us this way.’ Ally finishing to huge applause, people screaming...
That was fucking beautiful. As they come off the stage...
REZ is right there waiting for them...
Ally? Ally, that was unbelievable... What you did up there. (CONTINUED)
Thank you... Ally turns to grab Jack, but he’s already walked away...
I don't know if you know anything about me, about where I've come from. I'm Rez Gavron. Alley’s incredulous look --
I know who you are.

What you have right now goes way beyond just this. There's people who need to hear what you have to say musically. This is not normal stuff. It's really amazing what you're doing. I think you have it all. I do. And the question to you is, ‘What do you want?’ I'm in that position, to put you wherever you want to be. She thinks about this, she’s never really thought about it.
I don't... I don't have... I gotta talk to Jack? OFF Ally’s look --
Jack, eyes glazed over, past gone, but smoking a joint anyway, listens to Ally --
He said he thought Interscope Records might really wanna sign me... and he said that he has this wonderful studio... with a beautiful live room. Jack doesn’t say anything...
And these amazing producers he wants to bring in to record my songs. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
And he loves, um, ‘Look What I've Found.’ Remember the song I wrote at the diner? Remember, when we were on the motorcycle?
Yeah. Hard to tell if Jack’s even listening. He leans over to put his joint in the ashtray... His balance in question...
Yeah? I mean, it was so nice talking to him, and he really believes in me. THUNK! Jack crashes to the floor --
You all right, Jack? He's okay. He's fine. He does this all the time. Jack gets up and causally walks away without the slightest bit of acknowledgment to Ally’s career-shifting moment...
Hey, Jack? He keeps walking... Ally follows him into --
Jack doesn’t say anything... He turns to her.
What's going on? Jack still doesn’t say anything. She comes closer into him.
What're you doing? Jack takes a CREAM PUFF and smashes it into her face and mouth --
(laughing) You jealous fuck.
I'm so happy for you. (CONTINUED)
Oh, you are? He rubs it in more.

Jackson! Why're you so jealous, boy? She then grabs a handful of cream and rubs it into his hair, and she suddenly pulls him onto the bed... rolls on top of him despite the food... holding him... kissing him...
We RACK FOCUS TO the b.g. seeing glass and people behind it... Rez and Jack watching her... and we realize we are inside a RECORDING STUDIO...
(into mic) I'm so sorry. I'm, I'm sorry.
(over speakers) No, you're fine. We'll do it again. I'm gonna cue you in. (into mic) One, two... And the percussive piano chords start to play, an echo of what she started to write in the diner --
(into mic; singing) ‘I'm alone in my house...’ But it’s not quite right...
(over speakers) One second, one second. Listen to my cue. We'll come right in, okay?
So, should, uh... Well, uh... I'm sorry, but will I sing in the beginning? (CONTINUED)

So you're gonna hear the second line, and then I’m gonna start recording. She starts again, Jack and Rez listening to her singing. And Jack sensing this isn’t going well... knowing you only get one bite of this apple... looking at Rez... who is not even looking, but looking down at his phone --
(to Rez) I think I got an idea that might help out, all right?
Yeah, please. Be my guest.
(into mic) That was really good up to that point.
I'm just gonna go in there for a second, all right?
All right, Jack. Jack goes out and into...
Jack comes in, stopping the recording.
(apologetic) I've never sang with a track before. He backs her tenderly against a wall, hands on the wall on either side of her face, leaning close, whispering to her...

Listen, you know what I think it is -- I think it's because you need your piano. I think if you're playing it and singing it... and then with the rhythm... She takes a breath, trying to reset... (CONTINUED)
I always play it on the piano.
So I'm just gonna have them fly one in, and we'll try it there... and see where it goes.
You think that's okay? She looks at him... trusting him... and he moves his hands to let her go...
Thank you.
I got you. You're doing great. You okay?
No, I'm so nervous.
You look so beautiful.
Thank you. Jack and Ally kiss taking us to --
A PIANO, Ally at the keys, Jack seated next to her. She begins again --

(into mic; singing) ‘I'm alone in my house, I'm out on the town, I'm at the bottom of the bottle, I've been knockin' ‘em down, I can't get back up on my feet, See the lights on the street like stars, But look what I found, Look what I found.’ And it makes all the difference in the world, her voice popping with the music to make one spectacular, undeniable mix... And Rez knows it.  71.
Dancers stretch with Ally. RICHY, choreographer- extraordinaire, walks in like he owns the place (he does).
(to the dancers) Oh, so you guys have already met the new girl, have you? (noticing Rez in the corner) Rez! What's the plan?
Yo, thanks for doing this, man. I appreciate it.
LEGS DANCING FURIOUSLY IN THE F.G. ALLY’S NEW SONG, “HEAL ME” PLAYS LOUD --
We see Ally rehearsing with Richy and the two Dancers, a contemporary dance number... Ally and the dancers pouring sweat... Rez continues to watch from the back. The MUSIC CUTS --

This is pop music, kids. We have a battle to do, okay? You are the troops, so if I call you troops... just know that we're going into battle. What are my lyrics, Ally? Richy keeps instructing vocally the beats, they continue to refine the moves... And dancing --
(singing; dancing) ‘Just don't keep me waiting...’
(dancing with them) Yes! Again, give me that. Self. Break! Yes! (CONTINUED)

(singing; dancing) ‘When I can't inspire myself, I need you to provide for me.’ The dancers continue as Ally goes to the back of the studio and over to Rez... The dancers in the f.g. Rez looks over to the dancers...
This is just fine-tuning and creating an image. They watch the dance moves, fast, sharp, mechanical...
Yeah. I know, I just don't wanna lose, like, you know... the part of me that's talented.
I'm not gonna let you lose that piece.

Okay. She nods her head, he’s getting through. INT. JACK’S HOUSE - DAY Musical instruments, a microphone, recording equipment... Jack on the sofa, hears the door open, then a chiming sound... A LITTLE AUSTRALIAN LABRADOODLE PUPPY comes running up to him, all love.
Hey, you? Who are you? Ally comes in, holding a leash, dog food by her side.
Thought we could use some company... Jack looks at the new dog tag: CHARLIE.
Hey, Charlie! Jack and Ally snuggle up with the puppy. (CONTINUED)
What are we gonna do with you? Oh, he's beautiful! He's got your eyelashes.
(as dog) ‘You can't send me back. I'm too cute.’ He looks up to Ally, pure delight on his face.
Ally straddles Jack in the bathtub. She puts MASCARA on his eyelashes, he’s playfully resistant.
This has never been done before, just so you know. She ever so gently places a BLACK TAPE EYEBROW on his face.
It actually has been done before. Jack and Ally kiss. EXT. JACK’S HOUSE - NIGHT LOOKING IN. Jack and Ally in bed...
Jack at the piano, working something out. INT. JACK’S HOUSE - CLOSE ON HANDS - DAY EATING SOME TAKEOUT CHINESE FOOD...
Jack and Ally are on the sofa together, enjoying their food. They're quiet, enjoying the companionship...
(looks at her) Would you come with me to Memphis? (CONTINUED)
Vulnerable 74.
What are you talking about?
I have to do some soul-crushing work there... But it keeps the lights on and then some. So I should be grateful, but it's just kind of... never what I thought I'd wind up doing. to say the least.
I've made peace with it, though. Anyway, if you wanna come, I thought we'd have a laugh, at the very least.
(wants to, but...) Rez wants to keep me here because they rushed out the single... They were so excited that they want me to finish the album. So I'm working on that.
Listen to what you just said. People wanna hear what you have to say.
I know. I...
That's the stuff right there. (face-to-face) Hey, hey. Take it in. She smiles.
Thank you, by the way.
Thank you for what?
Giving me a home. This place never felt like one before.  75.
People costumed as PILLS dancing around giving out pamphlets, PHARMACEUTICAL KIOSKS set up in a horseshoe surrounding an empty stage where EMPLOYEES prep as people start to file into the chairs...
Jack takes out a pill bottle... he takes his boot and smashes the pills and snorts them off the table... He puts the remainder of the crushed pills in a glass and chases it with a big swig of gin.

The band is playing, but Jack’s not there. Everyone is waiting for him. Then, finally, Jack, a gin on the rocks in his hand, obviously two sheets to the wind, coming out to join his band to large applause. Jack looking out at the audience, a sea of name tags... He puts on his guitar.
Oh, fuck.
Jack, you okay? Jack? And as he plays, drunk, loaded, but good enough to be passable and keep on his feet...

We’re OVER Ally’s SHOULDER as she’s breathing, getting ready to go on... We PULL OUT and the music starts and she comes on and sings. However, the dancers are not a part of this choreographed number as intended...

(into mic; singing) ‘Treat me like your patient, Just don't keep me waiting, Or I'll just be wasted, In a crowd of the lonely, I need you to inspire me, When I can't inspire myself, I need you to provide for me...’ Backstage, Rez sees the DANCERS, very much not on stage. (CONTINUED)
Is there a reason why you're not up there?

‘Lay me down, lay me down now, Lay me down, touch my spirit, ooh, Lay me down, lay me down now, Lay me down, Heal me, God knows nothin’ else is gonna, Gonna heal me, Oh, before it's too late, Won't you steal me, Steal me all the way from myself, Won't you heal me?’
Ally and Rez just offstage, crowd now dancing to a DJ that has taken the stage. She’s still in her outfit... She and Rez speaking loud over the noise.
(panting) Hey!
Pretty incredible.
Did Jack show up?
I haven't heard from him.
What do you mean, you haven't heard from him?
I haven't heard from him all night.
I haven't been able to find him. I called him three times.
Listen, what happened with the dancers there? (CONTINUED)
Well, I just thought, you know, that I should do it alone... It's just, it's so overwhelming. With the hair, and the --

You can't go rogue on me. You have to understand that this is what I do... You have to trust me, okay? So, if I give you a couple of dancers... don't not use them and then miss a couple of steps, okay? We also have to change your hair. We have to change the color of your hair. She's still a little lost, thinking about Jack until --
What's wrong with my hair?
I'm thinking platinum, or...
I don't wanna be fucking blonde. I am who I am, and I'm worried about Jack.
I will find Jack, okay? I will find him. OFF Ally --
A figure steps into a sun-blistered sky and leans INTO the FRAME, REVEALING GEORGE “NOODLES” STONE.
Jack. I feel like we've done this before. Didn't think we'd do it so soon, man. We see that Jack is looking up at him, lying in a field of ivy. Rough night.
Come on, bro. Get up. All right. There we go. (CONTINUED)
Noodles helps Jack stumble to his feet. They head for the house...
In my mind, I made it to the door.

I almost didn't wake you. You looked so comfortable. EXT. NOODLES’ YARD - MOMENTS LATER Noodles smokes a cigarette, Jack sitting off to the side, still recovering from the night’s antics... Noodles’ wife PAULETTE, wearing a bathrobe, watches from the porch.
How you doing?
Well, you know, I've seen better days, I guess. I apologize for... disrespecting your property... or whatever I did.
No apologies necessary.
It’s fine.
You want some coffee?
(to Paulette) That would be great, why don't you put some on, and we'll come in, in a minute?
Okay. She walks off when Jack sees Noodles’ SON peering out the window.
That's him, right? That's your boy. (CONTINUED)
Jack, he's as old now as you were when I met you. Jack laughs. He looks a little worse for wear...
Saw you on YouTube. That video with the girl.
Yeah.
It made me happy, man. You looked like you. You were just... doing it, bro.
She writes, too.
She wrote that tune?
Yeah. Bunch of others, too. Got hooked up with some manager guy, wants to... You know...
She's good, bro.
I know. Noodles looks at him... never shy...
Maybe she's a way out. Jack regards his old friend...

Ain't nothing to be afraid of, bro. You know, it's like... You float out at sea, and then one day, you find a port. Say, ‘I'm gonna stay here for a few days.’ A few days becomes a few years. And then you forgot where you were going in the first place. And then you realize, you don't really give a shit about where you were going... 'cause you like where you're at. That's how it is for me. I like where I'm at. (CONTINUED)
Jack takes this in.
I didn't even realize I liked it so much... till I saw your ass sleeping in the grass this morning. They laugh, but Jack’s hangover has got the best of him.

Yeah, come on, man. You can rest in my daughter's room, bro. INT. NOODLES’ DAUGHTER’S ROOM —- LATER Sleeping in the bottom bunk bed, pink blankets half pulled over him. He starts to wake up -- Jack looks up and, like a vision of an angel, he sees Ally standing in the doorway... But this isn’t a vision and she comes to the bed, standing over him, looking him over. He doesn’t look well. Then -- Ally kicks him.
I thought of, like, a million things to say to you on the plane... that I can't remember. He’s too hungover to say anything. Ally gathering herself.
Jack...
Glad you're here. You did make it to Memphis after all. (beat) Fuck. He takes her hand. She sits on the bed next to him.
I won't do this again. I won't come and find you. Next time, you can clean up your own mess. You understand me? He nods his head. (CONTINUED)
How was the show? Despite everything, they’re on this journey together and Ally let’s him in... If only for a moment --
It was fucking awesome. I cut the dancers.
Dancers?
Yeah.
Ah. Good. Fucking dancers. All you need to do is sing. But she needs him to hear her --
You made me so upset.

I'm sorry. INT. NOODLES’ DINING ROOM - LATER Ally sits with Noodles and his FAMILY (Paulette; FRANKIE, his daughter; and LEO, his son) all sitting at the dining room table, a HOME-COOKED MEAL at the center, family- style.
I saw that video on YouTube. It was great.
Thank you so much. The little girl staring at her. Noodles sees Jack in the kitchen. Jack quietly waves him over...
Excuse me one second. Ally and the family continue their small talk as Noodles makes his way to --  82. NOODLES’ KITCHEN Jack leans in -- their conversation in whispers.
What's going on?
Do you have pliers or something? NOODLES’ DINING ROOM Ally eats, Frankie continues to stare.
I don't know where my mom is.
I can understand that.
I think you're pretty.

Me? You think I'm pretty? Thank you. I think you're pretty. NOODLES’ MUSIC ROOM A GUITAR on a stand... Jack walks over to it. The HEADSTOCK has the excess six-strings LOOPED. He bends the D STRING and clips it with the pliers, taking it with him. He starts to twist and bend it back on itself... NOODLES’ DINING ROOM Noodles, picking up where he left off --
(to Ally) It was real great, and then Jack tells me you wrote the song.
Yeah, he got me to start singing my own songs again.
He has a way of, he has a way of doing that. (CONTINUED)
(watching Jack’s return) Yeah, he does. Jack joins them at the table. Noodles starts to go into a story with the kids when Jack leans over to Ally --
(whispering) I understand what you said. Jack leans in further...
What the hell are you... Jack slides something onto her left hand “ring finger” -- the guitar string twisted into a MAKESHIFT ENGAGEMENT RING... They look at each other.
(laughing) Are you kidding?
(quietly) Well, that's a stupid thing I just did.
(quietly) No. It's not stupid. Ally lifts up her left hand showing her “engagement ring.” They all erupt with love and encouragement. Noodles looking at Jack, smiling to him.
(to Noodles) Is that what you were doing when you left the table?
I don't know. He told me he was looking for some pliers. I didn't know what he was going to do. I didn't think he was gonna ‘do it’ do it. (CONTINUED)
Well, that's just temporary.
No, no, no. Jack, wait a minute. Let's anoint this.
Good idea! We've got two Let's do it today. Yo, for witnesses. real. Ally looks at Jack... They can’t be serious...
I'll call my cousin right now. It's Saturday. Nobody's gonna be in there. Let's go.
I mean... (to Jack) You really wanna do that?
That place has magical quality to it.
(laughing) It what? It ‘has a magical quality?’
It does.
What do you mean? I mean that church is special. They are serious.
I'll take you to get a dress.
There you go, right there.
It'd be great! Okay, you're coming with us for sure because you're the... And as the excitement continues, Ally turns to Jack, his smile...
I can't believe this. What am I doing? Okay, sure.  85.
“I DON’T KNOW WHAT LOVE IS” carries us from shot to shot... JACK AND ALLY WALK THE AISLE, THE STONE FAMILY IN TOW. HUGS ALL AROUND FROM THE PASTOR -- A REUNION.

head_text.subj: A PASTOR WITH JACK AND ALLY, NOODLES, HIS FAMILY AROUND.

text: I do. I do. JACK AND ALLY KISS, NOODLES AND FAMILY CLAPPING.
Congrats, man.
I listened to what you said.
I'm glad you did.

ONSTAGE, the energy here is palpable. It’s a celebration of musicians, not singers... A man on the horn, the trumpet player taking over, and then NOODLES at the drums going at it, a veteran to the trade... With a wide smile, points to Jack and Ally in the PACKED AUDIENCE... Noodles waving them up on stage... the music never stopping... Ally and Jack rub CAKE ICING on each other’s noses. Then they rub it on Noodles. Ally tosses a BOUQUET.
The MUSIC TAKING US TO -- END MONTAGE.  86.
Ally’s debut album -- ALLY. Her hair now RED, vibrant, exciting, new...
Jack getting off the hotel phone and Ramon sitting across the room on the couch, typing on his phone.
Lot of people downstairs?
Yeah.
She better come out soon, before they leave.
What, want me to check on her?
I think we're gonna have to go pretty soon, so...
All right. Ramon gets up. Jack watches him go over to the BATHROOM DOOR.
Ally. I'm coming in. Before she answers, he opens the door and slips in --
He leans against the door.
Ally. A beat.
Yeah. (CONTINUED)
Ally is in an empty bathtub, the shower curtain obscuring her.
What're you doin' in the tub? He pulls back the curtain and Ally, with LONG, RED HAIR, is sitting on the bathtub floor in an EVENING GOWN.
This is so weird. I don't know who the hell I think I am. I... One song is fine... but to put out a whole record, I don't know what the fuck I was thinking.
I don't know about all of that, but you definitely look like a star.
Really?
Yeah.
Rez sits across Jack now, two men waiting for their girl.
What do you think of the hair and the look and the...?
Well, I discussed it with her.
Yeah.
I think it looks great.
Was that your choice, or...?
No, it was actually hers. (beat) No drink?
What's that? (CONTINUED)
No drink? Jack nods, fully aware of the implications Rez is alluding to.
No socks? Rez seemingly has no socks on.
Touché. Touché, mate.
Yeah, I could never get used to that... the idea of not wearing socks. Your feet get all sweaty...
(laughing) No, I actually am wearing socks. They're these kind of little female insert socks... that work with these shoes.
Oh. Oh, you are. You're just hiding them.
(laughing) Yeah, I'm just hiding them. That's right. INT. CHATEAU MARMONT - THEIR ROOM - BATHROOM —- CONTINUOU

Ally and Ramon are sitting in the bathtub... Ramon pulls out his phone and, with a few swipes, pulls up a video... He hands it to her... We see her melt. VIDEO: It’s the gang from THE BLEU BLEU all together in the dressing room --
(through phone) Okay, now is this thing... Yeah, there it is. Oh, that's a good light. Here, hold this for me, baby. Hey, Ally, girl! Wait, hold on. Come here, Sooki, Donte. Come here. (CONTINUED)
(through phone) I put my Jackson titties on!
Congratulations, Ally!/We miss youll! (Etc.)
(through phone) We love you!
(at phone) I love you, too.
(through phone) All right, girl, please come back soon. We done put Etta in your station, girl. They play around for the camera --
Ally and Ramon walk in.
The queen is here!
(laughing) Stop!
(her look) Wow! Ally looks up to Rez, then to Jack. She lets out a big breath. It’s all happening at once...
What do you think?
It's beautiful.
You. ‘SNL.’ Alec Baldwin hosting.
Did you get it? Did you get it? (CONTINUED)
Season finale.
No fucking way. No, you got it.
Oh, my God! That's incredible! Thank you.
Congratulations! Bitch!
Oh, my gosh!
We have to get downstairs. Everyone’s waiting for you. Come. Let's go.
Okay. And they start to move off, but Jack takes her hand --
(to Rez) You know what? Can I just talk to her for one second outside? Before Rez can say anything, he takes her out of the room and onto --
And we see Ally and Jack looking out to the Sunset Strip below and a view of a GIANT BILLBOARD: ALLY, the cover of her debut album. They stare at the billboard...
It doesn’t do you any justice, I’1l tell you that.
You always said you liked my nose.
I love your nose.
It's real big up there. (CONTINUED)
Jack pulls Ally takes Ally looks
I wish it was bigger up there. The whole thing should just be your fucking nose. Fuck all those people who ever said anything. Just put a billboard of your fucking nose up there.
(laughing) That’s so ridiculous. her in, almost whispering into her ear.
Listen, if I just don’t say this, I‘ll never forgive myself.
What?

If you don't dig deep in your fucking soul... you won't have legs. I'm just telling you that. You don't tell the truth out there, you're fucked. All you got is you, and what you wanna say to people... and they are listening right now, and they're not gonna be listening forever. a deep breath.

Trust me. So, you gotta grab it. And you don't apologize, you don't worry about why they're listening... or how long they're gonna be listening for... you just tell ‘em what you wanna say. ‘Cause how you say it is the stuff of angels. up at him with tears in her eyes.
Two dwarfed figures on the balcony going back into the room...  92.

Ally in rehearsals with her dancers and Richy, the choreographer. They dance to the music and his count, one of Ally’s new hit songs, “HAIR, BODY, FACE.” INT. “SNL” — NIGHT ALEC BALDWIN walks to the stage with a FEMALE ASSISTANT DIRECTOR in tow. There is a smattering of applause.
Thirty seconds. Red mark. (beat) Alec in twenty. Jack watches from below, back behind the pit and the standing audience.
(over radio) Fifteen.
(over radio) All right, stand by, guys. Here we go, ready? Song one.
(over radio) Stand by, Alec. Ally waits backstage. We see monitors with “SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE” in the control room.
(over radio) Ready four. Cue dissolve four.
(over radio) Alec in five seconds. (through radio) Four, three, two, one...
(over radio) And go four. Dissolve four... and cue Alec!
(to camera) Ladies and gentlemen... Ally. (CONTINUED)
(over radio) Dissolve one. The audience cheers. We PAN OVER TO -- lights exploding upon the stage, revealing Ally front center stage.

(into mic; singing) ‘Why do you look so good in those jeans, Why'd you come around me with an ass like that, You're makin’ all my thoughts obscene, This is not, not like me,’ She is the definition of a pop star. The song: vibrant, electric, catchy as all hell, and completely unrecognizable to Jack.

(into mic; singing) ‘Why you keep on texting me like that, Got other things I need my mind on, yeah, Other responsibilities, This is not, not like me, Why did you do that, Do that do that do that do that, Do that to me,’ The song goes into its generational anthem chorus, the crowd begins to jump in unison to the beat, a slave to her command of the song -- Jack saunters off, weaving his way farther into the bowels of the dark --

The sound slightly receding as he makes his way across into a place less populated. He spots a MONITOR, a live feed to the broadcast, the camera doing acrobats to mimic the energy of the song. He pops open a beer, watches until --
The caterpillar becomes the butterfly. (CONTINUED)
Jack turns and takes in his brother...
(pleasantly surprised) What the hell are you doing here?
I'm in town for a gig. Been working for Willie. (Jack can’t hear) I've been working for Willie.
No shit.
Yeah. Thought I'd stop by and check her out.
